bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, May 14, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison discusses the Lazear Building dedication program at Washington and Jefferson College. He is considering inviting Moran and Kissinger to the dedication. Hutchison intends to locate Mabel Lazear as well.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, May 14, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
May 14, 1940

div1.p:
I am delighted to have your letter of
May sixth and of course I have been intensely
interested in all that you have written and in the
photographs which you have sent. I am very sorry
to hear that Kahler has had to have an appendectomy,
but it is good to know that he is well and has
returned hom. Give him my regards and tell him
that we have had all the sickness from him that we're
going to take.

The more I think about it, the more you
write about it, the more I am inclined to believe that
if Moran comes for the dedication that we should
also have Kisinger, and I think we can bear that
expense if you are contributing Moran's expense.
You do not mention this in your letter but I
suppose that later you will let me know what his
reaction was to this possibility.

I appreciate your inquiry concerning
Mrs. Lazear's address. I do not have it and never
have had it, but I have intended to start the search
for it. Your inquiry spurred me on and I have now
written to Doctor Parran, to Johns Hopkins Medical
School, and to one of the Lazear family in Pittsburgh
in the hope that I might find out where she is.
If I get anything on it I will let you know right
away.

I will think more about the question of
what can be done for Moran if he comes. At first thought,
I am a little bit afraid of the matter of an honorary
degree. An honorary Master's Degree doesn't amount to
anything anyway and I just question whether the honorary
degree of any kind would be justified or appropriate.
I will be glad to talk it over with the trustees and
see what their reaction is. I do think that Moran and
Kisinger, if he comes, should be very markedly recognized
somewhere in the program, but I am not sure that the
Doctor Philip S. Hench
-2-
May 14, 1940
honorary degree would be approved. As I say, I will
keep studying this matter and I will keep in touch with
you on this matter.

Give my love to Mary. I hope you were a
great help to her on the arduous duties of this trip!
div1.closer:
Affectionately yours, Ralph Cooper Hutchison Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
